newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity ends up on cash, weather, outage.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity ends up on cash, weather, outage.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures settled higher Tuesday, extending Monday's gain on firming cash market prices, forecasts of cool, wet weather and plant outages in the western U.S.
"I'm a little surprised by the run-up, but you do have those outages," said a Houston futures trader.
A number of plant shutdowns in the western U.S. and cool temperatures in the Northwest again drove spot bulk electricity prices higher.

Day-ahead power prices for firm, peak delivery at the California-Oregon Border (COB) rose more than a dollar to $13.00-14.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), while those at Palo Verde (PV) were up 75 cents at $15.50-16.50.
May COB settled up 39 cents at $11.07 after posting a high of $11.30. June COB ended up 37 cents at $11.40. Other active COB finished flat to 45 cents higher.
May PV settled up 11 cents at $15.31, near the low end of the 25 cent trading range. June PV ended up four cents at $16.30. Other PV months finished 10 to 34 cents higher.
Forecasts called for temperatures near to eight degrees below normal levels through Friday in the Pacific Northwest, with rain and mountain snows Wednesday through Friday.
In the Southwest, temperatures were expected to be five to 10 degrees below normal with above normal amounts of precipitation through Friday.
The 1,073 megawatt (MW) Diablo Canyon unit 2 in central California is expected to returned to service as early as tomorrow after being taken off line last Saturday to repair a feedwater pump line.
In addition to Diablo Canyon 2, the 750 MW unit 2 at the Mohave coal-fired power plant in Nevada was shut Saturday for planned maintenance. The unit is expected to stay down until May 11.
A 750 MW unit at the Navajo coal-fired plant in Arizona was heard still idled for repairs, which could take as long as two weeks.
The 1,158 MW WNP-2 nuclear plant in Washington was idled last Thursday for maintenance until summer.

Brokers and traders cautioned the rise could end once cash prices show signs of easing, and the 1,221 MW Palo Verde nuclear unit 3 in Arizona and the 1,070 MW San Onofre nuclear unit 2 in southern California resume full output after both units restarted this past weekend.
NYMEX estimated 309 COB and 263 PV contracts were sold, higher than 258 COB and 212 PV lots Monday.
